If you place your feet wider apart and do leg press like this, you'll more adductors and glutes. If you place your feet low and do leg press like this, you'll work more quads. If you place your feet close together, you'll work slightly more outer quads.

title: Best Scientific Leg Workout For 2025
description: Here's my leg day based on science and experience. The seated leg curl for the hamstrings. This gets my knees nice and warm ...
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: Alright, this is my leg workout based on science and experience. Up first, the seated leg curl for the hamstrings. This gets my knees nice and warm for squats, and I usually pick seated overlying leg curls because this study showed they cause about 1.5 times more muscle growth. Next I do Smith machine squats for the quads and glutes. Here I get as deep as I can and explode out of the hole. Doing these on the Smith allows me to push my last set to failure without worrying about dumping the bar. After that, it's the Romanian deadlift for the glutes and hamstrings. Here I focus on pushing my hips back without allowing my lower back to round. Using straps on these to smirk, your glutes and hams should be stronger than your grip. Then I do leg extensions for the quads. Here I set the seat back to get a deep stretch and erectus femoris. On my last set I do myoreps beyond failure. Basically, rest for a few seconds, crank another three reps, and repeat. Then I superset two sets of hip adductions for the inner thighs with two sets of hip abductions for the glutes. And then four sets of standing calf raises.

title: THIS Is Optimal Technique For Muscle Growth
description: Full technique study here: https://www.mdpi.com/2411-5142/9/1/9.
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: My first scientific study is officially published, and it answers the question, what is optimal training technique? Here's what we found out. First, range of motion is the most important factor. You need to use a range of motion that gets the muscle fully stretched. You can do that by using a full range of motion, with a deep stretch, or by using long length partials. The second thing we found was the optimal lifting tempo. Each rep you do should last 2-8 seconds. That means you could do anything from a 1 second positive and a 1 second negative to a 1 second positive and a 7 second negative. The specific tempo doesn't seem to matter as much as simply controlling the negative and not just letting the weight free fall. And cheat reps do seem like a bad idea, but there's no study comparing ego lifting to strict form lifting yet. So that's the study we're going to do next, and I'll keep you guys posted on the results.

title: Full LEG WORKOUT to help grow your LEGS!

transcript: Alright, here's my full leg routine to help me add size to my legs. So I start off with 3 sets of 5 heavy barbell squats, then I drop the weight and do 3 more sets of 8-10, and then I do 1 final set of 20. After that I do 4 sets of Romanian deadlifts, then leg extensions and leg curls, then I finish off with Bulgarian split squats, and cable pull-throughs.

title: The Problem With Ab Workouts
description: Most fitness influencers focus on fast-paced fat burning workouts that don't actually build your six-pack. Instead, you'd be much ...
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: The problem with most ab workouts that I see online is that most fitness influencers showcase these fast-paced, fat-burning style workouts that truly are a waste of time for the most part. That's because they don't actually get the abdominal muscles close enough to failure to stimulate meaningful hypertrophy. This is still good exercise, but it is essentially just another form of cardio. Sure, you'll burn a few calories, but you're not building your six pack. Instead, to get your six pack to really pop, you'd be much better off doing progressive overload training just like you would for any other muscle. You do that by loading the abs with weight, and you really only need two exercises. One weight-loaded crunch and one leg raise. That's it. Try to add a rep or some weight each week. This way, the next time you cut down, your abs will pop much better.

title: A Better Way To Do Leg Extensions
description: Should you do leg extensions with the seat up or back? Which position leads to the best quad muscle growth?
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: He always does his leg extensions like this. So with the seat up and his back more upright, so the way most people do them. But he does something different. He always sets the seat back and declines his torso. Who do you think will actually grow bigger quads? Well, a brand new study tested this. Scientists had people train with either the seat up position with their hips flexed at around 90 degrees, or with the seat back position with their hips flexed at 40 degrees. After 10 weeks of training, here's the cool part, there was no difference in quad growth except one head called the rectus femoris grew way better with the seat back. It saw 170% more growth. This is a huge difference because the rectus femoris is a huge head. Does this mean that your quads are gonna look like J-Cutlers in eight weeks as long as you set the seat back? No, the actual amount of muscle gain was only a few millimeters. But compounded over years of training, I do think that doing your leg extensions with the seat back will lead to your best possible gains.

The shape of your pelvis and hip capsule is unique to you. Your femur should freely move up and you should feel totally balanced. But if you don't, try elevating your heels on plates or better, Olympic shoes. Now pull yourself under the bar with a close stance, placing the bar on top of your traps. Keep the grip close. Hands as close to the shoulders as you can manage. Hinge your back together and pull the bar down into your traps to tension the back. Slide the knees forward, placing the hips under the bar. Stand steady. Then step deliberately. One, two. Tuck and level your hips. Lightly screw the feet into the ground to help stabilize the hips. Breathe deep into your belly and brace like expecting a punch. Slide the hips back very slightly. Sink straight down between your legs. Depth may vary, but strive to lower to at least parallel. Keep the bar over the middle of your feet with equal balance from heel to toe. And knees over toes in the same direction. Drive up, thinking. Keep knees forward and hips underneath. The hips and bar should rise at the same rate of speed.

title: How to Target Your LEGS

If you do stiff leg deadlifts like this, allowing your knees to drift back, you'll target some low back and glutes, but mainly hamstrings and adductors, and direct more of the growth higher towards the glutes. If you do leg curls seated or lying like this, you'll target the hamstrings, adductors, and the calf, and you'll direct more growth lower towards the knee. If you point your toes out, you will target the muscles on the outside. Point them in, more inside. If you do calf raises with your legs straight, you'll target both the gastroc and the lower soleus. If you do the seated calf raise like this, you will only target the lower soleus, with machines or a bar.

Go as low as you comfortably can and squeeze your quads to lift yourself up. Switch to body weight once you're strong enough. Third, Sissy Squats. Don't let the name fool you. These are hard. Grab a cable for balance and as you lean back, come up onto your toes and let your knees travel forward. Don't worry, studies show this won't hurt your knees. It'll make them stronger. title: Everyone Is Confused About Training To Failure
description: Learn the art and science of of training to failure. This short will demonstrate how and when to push yourself to failure during your ...
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: Should you train to failure? Well, the latest highest quality study in experience subjects actually found no difference between taking a set all the way to failure versus stopping one to two reps shy. But the problem is, if you never take any sets to failure, how are you supposed to know what one to two reps in the tank feels like? So that's why on pretty much every exercise, I just take the last set all the way to failure. Let me show you what that looks like for one of my leg days. So on the leg press, as you get close to failure, you're going to be really tempted to just let the weight free fall. But it's extremely important that as you do those last few reps, you still control the negative. Going to failure on the leg curl is kind of interesting because after you reach failure, you can't get the pad quite all the way down. You can still probably crank out another two or three partial reps. This is what I'll do on my last set. Going to failure on Bulgarian Swiss Squats is absolutely brutal, so I'd recommend doing two sets tops, your last set to failure. And again, with leg extensions, make sure you control the negative, especially as you get close to failure.

title: Get NOTICEABLY BIGGER Calves With This Technique
description: The calves are the hardest muscle to grow, but scientists recently discovered three solutions to their stubbornness. First, the ...
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: The calves are the hardest muscle to grow. A scientist that recently discovered three solutions to their stubbornness. First, the standing calf raise is so insanely better than the seated calf raise. The gastropnemius grew more than 10 times more with standing versus seated, and the soleus grew the same. That's because when you bend your knee, you reduce the stretch on your gastro. But the key isn't that you're standing, the key is that you have a straight knee. Second, we all already knew that the calves needed deep stretch, but even more so than we realized. When you do calf raises, don't stop until you literally can't move the weight at all. This study found that the calves grew better from doing tiny partials beyond failure, even 8th reps and 10th reps. Though, until you literally can't budge the weight third, surprisingly, where you point your toes matters. Pointing your toes straight ahead hits the entire calf evenly. Pointing your toes out grows your inner calves more, and pointing your toes in grows your outer calves more. These researchers said that alternating your toes in and your toes out may cause the best growth of both heads.

title: How To Leg Press With Perfect Technique
author: Jeff Nippard
transcript: Leg Press Checklist. If you take all five, you have a perfect leg press. The last one is what most people are confused about. First, place your feet for your goal. A higher foot position will target more glutes. A lower foot position will target more quads. How wide you go doesn't matter as much, but a round shoulder width is usually best. Point your toes slightly out. Second, control the weight down on every rep. Most people load up as many plates as they can, but then just let the weight free fall. It's better to go lighter and resist the weight on the negative. You want to notice your quads lengthening on the way down. Third, go as deep as you comfortably can. This is the most important step. For quad and glute growth, the deeper, the better. If you bottom out the machine, add an extra pad behind your back, or drop the weight back until you can get deep enough first, then build the weight back up. Fourth, grip the handles hard. As you do the positive, pull up on the handles to keep your glutes firmly planted on the seat. Fifth, lock out. It is generally safe to fully lock the knees out, but I try not to snap my knees at the top. I'll usually maintain a very slight knee bend at lock out.

Push your hips back and slide the bar longer thighs until it passes your knees. Step 4. Stay tight and pull back with your elbows to lift the bar up towards your stomach. Let your elbows flare out to about a 45 degree angle and squeeze your shoulder blades together to engage your back muscles. Step 5. Control the bar down and fully stretch your back muscles by letting your shoulder blades open up. Keep going until your arms are fully extended then repeat for another rep. Congrats, you've just done the perfect barbell row.

author: Davis Diley
transcript: Here's one of my all time favorite and most effective bicep workouts. I've been doing it for years and I want you to have it. Let's go. First, Cambered Bar Preacher curls for 4 sets of 12-15 reps. Push these as hard and as heavy as you possibly can, imagining that you're curling the weight up to the ceiling with your pinky and ring fingers. Next, Crush Grip Dumbbell Curls for 3 sets of 15 reps. These will get your biceps and forearms wider when looking from a front view. Keep your elbows in and constantly crush the dumbbell inwards with your grip as you curl up to the top. Then, Single Arm Dumbbell Hammer Curls with a staggered stance and the plane of your shoulders open up to the side, really controlling the negatives down and focusing on keeping the crease of your elbow facing the ceiling. Then, an isometric hold for absolute max time. Using the same dumbbell that you used for the Crush Grip Curls, keep your arm held at a 90 degree angle and your wrist held strong. Lock out the pain and fight it for as long as you can.

title: How to Deadlift: 5 Simple Steps

transcript: The world would be a better place if everybody had a perfect deadlift, don't you think? You're about to see the best set of steps for that perfect deadlift you've ever seen. Step 1. Approach the bar so that your shins are one inch away from the barbell, putting it directly over the middle of your foot. Step 2. Without bending your shins to the barbell, grab the barbell just on the outside of your shins. Do not move the barbell. Step 3. Push your knees forward until your shins meet the barbell, dropping your hips down into the position. Step 4. Push your chest through and pull your shoulders down towards your hips. Step 5. Push your knees out into your forearms and drag the barbell directly up your legs, keeping it in contact all the way until you're standing straight up and down. Then, push your hips back and lower the bar down to the floor, keeping it in contact with your legs the entire time. And that my friends is how you do a perfect deadlift. I'm going to keep the content coming. Follow for more.

author: Davis Diley
transcript: Here's one of my all-time favorite and most effective bicep workouts for getting an insane pump. It works every time. Let's go. Start off with dumbbell curls for seven sets of 10 reps, but here's the kicker. You're only going to rest for 30 seconds between each set. Choose a weight that feels easy to complete the first two to three sets with. Eventually, a searing burn will start to set in at the end of each set. But no matter what, grit through it, starting to curl the dumbbells individually if you have to. Then for three sets, pick up one of the dumbbells and start to perform the waiter's curl. With a slight lean forward, imagine that you're curling the insides of your hands right to your throat. Curl the dumbbell up under your chin, allowing your wrists to bend back and opening your palms up at the top.

title:
KNEES TO THEM YITTIES🥵🌶️

A lot of you struggle to see results with building your legs because you’re skimping on your gains doing half reps on the leg press machine!

So let’s break it down on how you can do this right:

✅Use a challenging weight that allows you to finish your sets and reps with QUALITY work

✅make sure your a$$ is glued to the seat, you can hold the handles the whole entire time to help you— when your butt starts to lift off the seat, that’s when your lower back starts to takeover the load

✅When executing your reps, you want to slowly bring your knees towards your yitties and pause at the bottom

✅Then push the weight away using your legs, and at the top of the exercise, your knees should be SLIGHTLY BENT to keep the tension on your legs and for you NOT to get injured or putting pressure on your knee joints

✅Keep your core braced to help support your back as you lift heavier loads overtime!

That’s it! 

Go ahead and give this one a try! And let me know how it goes🫶🥵
#legpress

author: nataleebfitness
transcript: Some of you guys jump onto the leg press and you have no fucking idea what you are doing. Foot placement on the leg press is everything and I'm going to show you how to do it. So if you want to hit your quads on the leg press, you want to be centered and you want your feet in the middle, okay? This means that when you push off and you bring your knees to your chest, you are solely using your quads. You drive out and you'll only feel it here, okay? If you want to hit your hips and like your outer thighs, you want your feet to be wide on the platform, okay? And you want your feet pointed outwards ever so slightly. This means that when you bring your knees to your chest, you'll feel it all here and when you drive out, you are using this part of your legs. If you want to hit your hamstrings and your glutes, so your hamstrings are the back of your legs and your glutes is your bum, you want your feet high up and you want it a little bit wider than in the center, okay? Again, bring your knees to your chest and you're going to use your hamstrings to drive out and that's where you'll hit. And then if you want to hit your calves, you want to put your feet on the bottom of the platform, half on, half off and you basically just want to do tippy toes. So you push it out with the front of your feet and you'll feel that solely in your calves. So next time you jump on the leg press, don't be clueless. Think about where you're putting your feet, think about where you want to hit and make sure you're targeting the right area.

title:
The main difference between the lat pull-down machine and the lat cable pull-down is in their setup and the way they target the muscles. 

1. Lat Pull-Down Machine: This machine typically has a fixed bar and is designed for a more controlled movement. You sit down, adjust the knee pad, and pull the bar down towards your chest. This setup can help isolate the latissimus dorsi muscles effectively and is often easier for beginners to use.

This can be great for building foundational strength in your lats. Since it provides a fixed path, it helps beginners focus on form and technique.

2. Lat Cable Pull-Down: This variation uses a cable system, which allows for a more fluid range of motion. You can adjust the angle of your pull and change your grip more easily, which can target different parts of the back muscles. It also allows for more versatility in your workout routine.

It adds versatility to your routine. By changing grips (wide, narrow, or reverse), you can target different areas of your back. Plus, the cable system allows for a more natural movement, which can help with muscle activation and stability.

By alternating between these two in your workouts, you can ensure comprehensive development of your back muscles, improve muscle balance, and prevent injuries. 

Remember Diet is 80% of your results ! So ensure that with doing the right workouts you are also sleeping and eating correctly !

title:
Wide Grip Lat Pulldown Tips:
1. Stabilize: Ensure the thigh pad is tightly secured against your thighs for stability.
2. Grip: Use a thumbs-over grip to better engage your lats.
3. Posture: Keep your chest up, shoulders down and away from your ears.
4. Elbows: Slightly tuck in your elbows as you pull.
5. Pull: Draw the bar towards your upper chest while keeping your forearms aligned with the cable.

transcript: Stop doing your dumbbell curls wrong. Listen, there's a few major mistakes that people make when they do dumbbell curls. And I want to share them with you in this video, but first I'd appreciate a follow. The first mistake that I see people making is choosing a weight that's too heavy. Listen, dude, anybody can curl 60 pounds if you're swinging using your whole body weight. Your bicep's ain't that strong, bro. What I want you to do is slow the rep down, make sure you control the movement, keep your core nice and tight. That's the first fix. The second mistake is not twisting your pinkies to the sky. Anytime you do a curl, you want to make sure you get a full contraction in that bicep. And for a full contraction, you need to rotate your pinky towards your bicep. Now, the third mistake that I see is people doing curls like this. Too fast, one after the other with succession instead of having a nice, slow controlled bicep curl that warrants a good stretch and a good contraction. Now add these tips to your next arm day and watch as your biceps explode. I'll see you in the next one.

title:
✅ Dumbbell Bicep Curl Variations (KNOW THE DIFFERENCE!)

If you use a supinated grip to perform bicep curls, you'll primarily work your biceps. If you use a neutral grip, you'll shift the emphasis to the brachialis and brachioradialis; you'll still be working your biceps but to a lesser extent. If you use a pronated grip, you'll shift even more workload to the brachioradialis and even less workload to the biceps.

author: Peter Miljak
transcript: Stop doing your bicep curls like this. First, I want you to actually do one arm at a time and I want you to slightly lean over the arm that you're working, making sure that your upper arm is perpendicular with the ground the entire time. Now, as you curl, what this is doing is it's lining up that upper arm in your bicep with that line of force of gravity, as opposed to curling like this with your elbows slightly flared out. Next, I want you to hold an offset grip with your thumb butted up against the end of the dumbbell. And what this is doing is it's placing majority of that weight of that dumbbell on the outside of your hand, making it harder for you to supinate at the top, which is gonna force you to squeeze your bicep a lot more. So you're gonna keep your chest up. I want you to make sure that your shoulder is stable and secure the entire time. I don't want it moving around. You're leaning over that arm and I literally want you to just think about bringing that forearm to your bicep while supinating at the top, squeezing that bicep, controlling that eccentric on the way down. And I even want you squeezing your tricep to fully lengthen that bicep. Again, I'm bringing that forearm to the bicep, squeezing the bicep, supinating, controlling that eccentric. Mm.

The seated row machine is a piece of strength training equipment designed to target the muscles of the upper body, particularly the back
and arms. It primarily focuses on strengthening the latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, trapezius, and biceps brachii.
Narrow Grip vs. Wide Grip: A narrow grip emphasizes lats and rhomboids, while a wide grip focuses more on smaller back muscles like middle trapezius and posterior deltoids. Upper back.

title:
3 Grip Variations for Seated Row: CLOSE vs. MEDIUM vs. OVER

1️⃣ Close Neutral Grip – Palms facing each other with a narrow grip. Focuses on the lower lats.

2️⃣ Medium Neutral Grip – Slightly wider grip, allowing better shoulder control. Engages the lats, middle traps, and rhomboids.

3️⃣ Wide Overhand Grip – Palms facing down with a wide grip. Targets the upper lats and rear delts.

Which grip do you prefer? Let me know in the comments! ⬇️

title:
Wide stance barbell squats

This exercise is perfect for strengthening the muscles of the femoral joint and the buttocks, it is recommended for athletes who have a lot of sports experiences.

Instruction
• It is recommended that you perform this exercise in a squat rack. Adjust the barbell in accordance with your height. Choose your working weight. Stand under the barbell so that it rests on the shoulders (just below the neck).
• Hold the bar with both hands and an upper grip at wider than shoulder width then lift it from the rack.
• Take a step back and stand with your feet wider than shoulder width then slightly turn your toes out to the sides. Keep your back straight. The head should always be raised; if you lower your eyes, you will lose your balance. This is the starting position.
• As you inhale slowly squat, bending your knees and pulling the pelvis back. Continue to go down until the hips are parallel with the floor.
• As you exhale rise back up to the starting position, transferring the weight to the heels and contracting the target muscles to their maximum point.
• Perform the required number of repetitions. Place the barbell on the rack.

Warning
• This exercise should be taken very seriously. If you have problems with your back, choose another exercise. If you are healthy then follow the technique to the letter and do not tilt the trunk back or forward, as this can cause back injury. 
• The squat is a safe exercise only if the correct technique is followed. 
• With proper technique the knees and the toes should be on the same line. If the knees go out beyond the toes then you are at risk of overloading the knee joints.

title:
Low Bar Squat vs High Bar Squat, know the difference. A high bar squat is when the bar is positioned on the upper traps closer to the neck. What this does is it makes your torso more upright as you come down allowing your knees to move more forward which targets more of your quads. 

A low bar squat is when the bar is placed lower on your back across the top of your rear delts. This leads to more forward lean of the torso placing more emphasis on the posterior chain muscles. #squats #barbellsquats #squatsworkout #powerlifting #bodybuilding #gymtok

This means that when you push off and you bring your knees to your chest, you are solely using your quads. You drive out and you'll only feel it here, okay? If you want to hit your hips and like your outer thighs, you want your feet to be wide on the platform, okay? And you want your feet pointed outwards ever so slightly. This means that when you bring your knees to your chest, you'll feel it all here and when you drive out, you are using this part of your legs. But make sure you don’t forget:

🏋️‍♀️ The leg press is a compound move that hits your quads, glutes, hamstrings, adductors, and calves—but by adjusting your foot position, you can really target specific muscles. 

Here’s how:

✨ For more Quads:
➖Place your feet low and hip-width on the pad. The deeper the knee bend, the more stretch you get in the quads.

🍑 For more Glutes:
➖Feet higher on the pad, hip-width apart, keeping your shins vertical. Less knee bend = more hip flexion and a bigger stretch in the glutes!

💪 For more Adductors (inner thighs):
➖Feet wide, toes slightly pointed out. This hits those inner thighs harder for more focus.

title:
The plank is a highly effective core training exercise. To perform it properly, keep the following key points in mind:
	1.	Place your hands naturally forward on the floor.
This helps reduce pressure on the shoulders and prevents the elbows from tucking in too close.
	2.	Keep your head aligned with your spine.
Look down at the floor—avoid tilting your head up or down to maintain a neutral neck position.
	3.	Protract your shoulder blades.
Don’t pinch them together—keep them slightly spread to stabilize the upper back and engage the serratus anterior.
	4.	Tuck your pelvis slightly and engage your core.
Avoid sticking your butt up or letting your lower back sag. Your body should form a slight arch, supported by strong core activation.
	5.	Keep your feet shoulder-width apart.
This provides better stability and balance, especially for beginners.
	6.	Focus your attention on your core.
Stay actively engaged—don’t just passively hold the position.

title: Days 176-180 of doing 100 Kettlebell Swings a Day in a ROW! 6 months in and I'm still swinging! As far as weightloss, my body's slown down in that department. I'm embracing it wholeheartedly because I know what my body starts to look like when I'm rapidly loosing weight- Loose Skin. When I lost 105 lbs naturally in my early 20s, it was a bit depressing to lose all the weight but still feeling like I had an abundance of skin. Years later when I turned 30 I lost 100 lbs again... this time it really got to me. Going from 245 lbs to 145 left me feeling deflated to say the least. When I started my current Journey August 1st of 2022 I weighed 215 lbs. Currently I'm maintaining 169-172ish that's still about 45 lbs gone! It took about a year, but I'm noticing my skin and physique is a lot more toned. Especially in my legs! I didn't have a goal when I set out on this current journey. I just didn't feel comfortable at 215. My goal was never to get down to 145 either. More and more I'm realizing my goal is to just be consistent. And to do the exercises my body craves, and to simplify my routine so it's as sustainable as possible. I don't want to have to lose 100 lbs again ever in my life. By doing these swings daily, I'm toning, and REALLY I love my walks! Just those two things alone have helped me lose weight, and maintain my weight while still enjoying somewhat regular food! Most of all I'm happy with the woman I see in the mirror everyday! Posting Month 6 Progress soon! title:
The free-weight dumbbell bench press is one of the most effective exercises, especially for those of us over 40! Here’s why it should be a staple in your workout routine:

1. **Promotes Muscle Retention:** As we age, muscle loss becomes a reality. Dumbbell bench presses help combat this by targeting multiple muscle groups (chest, shoulders, and triceps), ensuring you maintain and even build muscle strength over time.

2. **Enhances Shoulder Stability:** Dumbbells require more control than machines or barbells, engaging stabilizer muscles around the shoulders. This increased activation strengthens these supporting muscles, reducing the risk of injury—a crucial benefit as we get older.

3. **Improves Joint Health:** With free weights, you can move more naturally through your own range of motion. This reduces stress on the joints compared to fixed movements, making it easier on the shoulders and elbows, especially beneficial for aging joints.

4. **Balances Muscle Strength:** Dumbbells force each side of your body to work independently, helping to correct any strength imbalances. This balanced development is vital for preventing injuries and ensuring even muscle growth, especially as we age.

5. **Boosts Bone Density:** Weight-bearing exercises like the dumbbell bench press stimulate bone growth and help maintain bone density, which is crucial for preventing osteoporosis and fractures as we age.

title:
Outfit from @aybl - use code "DELTA" for 10% off.  Link in bio.

✅ Do THESE to GROW Your Triceps!

Setting the pulley to a high position and using an overhand (pronated) grip for cable triceps pushdowns activates all three heads of the triceps, with greater emphasis on the lateral head. Switching to an underhand (supinated) grip works slightly more of the medial head. To better target the long head, lower the pulley to chest height, face away from the machine, and perform overhead triceps extensions—this position places the long head under a greater stretch, enhancing its engagement.

If you switch to an underhand grip and do reverse grip triceps pushdowns like this, you'll slightly emphasize more medial head. If you set the pulley to chest height, face away from the cable and perform overhead triceps extension like this. You'll work more of the long head.

title: ✨ A quick mini tutorial on how to do a tricep push down using the cables at the gym
author: nubody_onlinecoaching
transcript: One of my favorite exercises for my triceps are tricep push downs and I'm going to show you guys how to do them properly. Personally, I like to use the rope. I feel like I get a better full extension with using the ropes. You want to start by stepping away from the cable column and then all we're going to do is we're going to push our hips back. So a slight hinge at the hips while keeping your core nice and engaged. So you want that tightness that you would get as if you sneeze or cough while keeping your back nice and straight. Now this is key when it comes to tricep push downs, okay? You want to keep those elbows nice and tight by the side of your body because all you really are going to be doing is extending all the way, keeping a nice straight arm and bending at the elbow, slowly bringing the rope back up to the forehead. So it's really just an extension and bending at the elbow, okay? What you don't want to do is you don't want to move your arms with it. This is not going to really work the triceps. Keep the elbows nice and tight by your side and then fully extend the arms out nice and straight. Like you see the triceps right now? They're flexing, okay?
